prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For Expecting My Food Deliverer to Knock on my Door?
I'm a new mom and get loads of packages delivered. I had handwritten signs that said "Do not Knock" for packages in various iterations that were ignored. I always wrote "Do not knock" in every checkout cart that offered "delivery options" notes. It never worked. So, I found a sign that had pictures of the corporate courier logos for attention. And it worked! Too well... We ordered dinner last night and it was 45 minutes late! UGH. Well... The food delivery person saw the sign and silently left it at the front door. It was ice cold when we realized what happened. Am I the asshole? My husband said we were asking for it. I think common sense should have prevailed.

[The Sign](https://imgur.com/gallery/rIFIXCr)
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The food delivery situation might be an unintended consequence. On the other hand, maybe the author should have considered that food delivery usually requires a different handling (like knocking) compared to packages. The sign might have been too broad, not differentiating between package and food deliveries.

But the key point is whether the author's expectation of the deliverer to knock for food is reasonable. The author had repeatedly specified "Do not knock" for packages, but food delivery usually involves a person waiting to receive the food, so common sense would suggest knocking. The deliverer did follow the sign's instruction, which the author created, but maybe the author didn't account for different types of deliveries. However, the sign's purpose was for packages, not food. The confusion here is between packages and food. The author might not be in the wrong because they didn't explicitly state exceptions for food. The deliverer might have misinterpreted the sign, but the author's intent was clear for packages. The issue is the sign's ambiguity. So, maybe the author isn't in the wrong because they can't be blamed for the deliverer's mistake in applying the sign to food. Alternatively, maybe they should have anticipated that the sign could affect food deliveries and adjusted accordingly. But since the sign included courier logos that might not cover food services, it's unclear. In conclusion, the author's main issue was the sign's ambiguity.
